quest_name: Mission? Well, look straight ahead. Now give me a

history.location_text:
Mission? Well, look straight ahead. Now give me a jump... higher! Even higher! One step forward. Squat down, stand up straight. One jump forward, one jump back - don't turn! Stand up, stop wincing and nursing your tail base... Not bad at all.

I think you are the one we need, Ranger. Our scholars invented a unique device, which was sent to the Institute of Inventions and Innovations on planet Bonnasis for patenting. Unfortunately, we didn't have time to test it thoroughly so now we can't complete the application for the patent. There is only one test remaining - field-testing - but it is the most important one. We have already rented a test lab in the Institute and invited stuntmen but they failed to complete the testing.

As a ranger, you must be perfectly trained. We will even pay you twice as much as a stuntman gets - it makes 65535 cr, if you go to planet Bonnasis (system Procyon) and manage to test the device. But keep in mind that the patent submission is due to expire, so you must do all the testing by 6 February 3000.
choices: I agree
history.reasoning: (auto-selected single choice)

history.location_text:
You took an aerocab that brought you to the Inventions and Innovations. It was near the Academy of Anthropological and Amorphous Anomalies. You entered and asked which way you should go.

A gloomy assistant accompanied you along the tortuous corridors. You met a Maloq with a stunt man's badge hopping with his crutches, then they carried by a litter with an unconscious man - your colleague. A gaal in a wheelchair saw where you were going. Then he approached you, gave you a sympathising look, and mentioned quietly: "Heh, he's so young", - after that he wheeled away.

The assistant brought you to the "Test laboratory No 13" and kindly opened the door.
- Ranger? - a fae stood up to meet you. - Nice to meet you, I'm professor Hab, I manage the testing of the device and collect all the information necessary for the patent application preparation. Have a sit.
You sat obediently on the offered chair.
- Stand up, now sit down again. Bounce on your toes. Higher. Still higher! Now hold your breath. Hold your left ear with your right hand and the right ear with your left hand... Not mine!!!
He measured your pulse and nodded with satisfaction.
- Excellent. Pulse, co-ordination, reflexes  - you are in perfect shape and this is very important for the "Jumper"'s testing. By the way, you may breathe.

You exhaled with relief:
choices: What exactly am I supposed to do?
history.reasoning: (auto-selected single choice)

history.location_text:
- You must test the jumping backpack - "Jumper". We rented a pavilion for the testing and tossed a facility. Your task is to go through the labyrinth made of hanging platforms jumping from one platform to another using the "Jumper". The labyrinth consists of the starting and finishing points and five rows of platforms between them.  Your task is to make a number of jumps to get from the starting point through the labyrinth to the finishing point . And you can jump only within the row you are at or onto the platforms of the next row.

Jumps require power consumption, which is measured in ergo and depends on the length of the jump. You will have two batteries  20 ergo each. One battery is active, and the other is spare. Our technicians promise that would be enough.

There are additional devices somewhere on the platforms, which allow you to replace the active battery, top it up or even get back to the starting point where you can charge the both batteries and start the testing from the very beginning. If you want to cancel the testing and, accordingly, abandon your fee, you can use the emergency return button.
choices: Take me to the scaffold... I mean, to the testing facility. I agree to stretch my legs a little bit... Lord forbid, of course!
Please give me more details about the labyrinth's configuration and explain how I can go through it.
What is the power consumption during jumping?
You said something about additional devices in the labyrinth...
Please tell me once again -what is my task?
Can you tell me more about the "Jumper"? What's the hang of this device?
What are your guarantees? Have you experienced any accidents?
Oh, no - the disability pension is not big enough to affect grasshopper.

Before starting, I need to refresh my knowledge of the specific power consumption rules and the layout of the labyrinth to calculate the most efficient path. I must avoid Violet-5 (a dead end) and use the even-numbered platform swapping mechanic strategically to consolidate my charges. Gathering all technical data now will prevent the "energy starvation" encountered in the Green row during previous attempts.

history.location_text:
Instead of answering Hab pointed to the window opening to the testing pavilion. There were half a dozen of platforms about two meters in diameter each hanging behind the window at a height of almost 20 meters. The distance between them was from 2 to 10 meters. The platforms were white with one coloured stripe along the edge.

- There are five rows of platforms here, each row is marked with a certain colour. The technicians changed the configuration many times already making the facility easier and safer, so I have only general information about its structure: 
- Starting point
- Yellow row - 4 platforms
- Red row - 4 platforms
- Violet row - 5 platforms, plus one battery charger
- Blue row - 4 platforms, the teleport can be used here
- Green row - 3 platforms, the teleport is active here too
- Final point - the testing is over here.

I would advise you to drag your heels here and study the facility's structure first. When you reach the Green or Blue row, you will be able to return to the starting point, charge your batteries and do the testing from the beginning. But note - you can do it just once.

history.location_text:
Depending on the length of the jump, the power consumption will be the following:

2 meters - 4 ergo 
3-4 meters - 5 ergo
5 meters - 7 ergo
6-7 meters - 8 ergo
8 meters - 10 ergo
9-12 meters - 15 ergo

Our technicians promise that 40 ergo will be enough to go through the labyrinth. You are given two batteries  20 ergo each. Only one battery can be active - its power is used for the jump. But you can replace the battery with the help of the special device - there are such samples in the test labyrinth.

history.location_text:
The professor wished you good luck and blessed you. Then he took you to the test pavilion.
- Note that the battery replacement devices are installed on the even platforms of each sector. Here is a portable teleport adjusted to return back here. You can use it only once - while passing the labyrinth' last two rows. The emergency return button means that you cancel the testing of just can't complete it. And in case of any accidents - well, you understand what I mean, mind your language and don't dirty the floor - our young ladies assisting in the lab have such a weak stomach.

You went up the stairs to the starting point. Meanwhile the professor and a dozen of his associates were making bets what platform you will fall from. 
"Snooks, lab rats", - you got furious and came to the edge. It is high! Round 20 meters, so the fall will be short but very painful. Well, you must jump. Which sector will you choose?

history.location_text:
Hardly had you landed onto the platform, an automated voice said:
"Active battery, current charge - 8 ergo. Boost charging function is active. Boost charging complete. Active battery, current charge - 20 ergo"

"Heh, I wish my spaceship had such a battery", - you thought enviously.

After landing onto the very edge of the platform, you saw a scratched inscription:
"Bob was h..." - after "h" it was chopped and a long deep scar along with five minor ones stretched to the edge of the platform.

The portable teleport started peeping on your belt. That meant it was active. It will help you to return to the starting point to charge the batteries and  - good luck again!

To Blue-4 (4 meters)

history.location_text:
Your last jump was unbelievably beautiful - a storm of applause came from underneath and in the last moment you realised that the crowd of on-lookers will soon turn into the crowd of victims because you were landing right on their heads. Fortunately, everything turned out well and nobody was hurt.

- At last! - the professor was shaking your hand in excitement. - We thought we would have to cancel the project due to excess life and health risk. The rectorate started to look awry at us when we receive the bills for the medicine. You deserved your award, Ranger, all you need to do now is to get back to your employer on the Bonnasis planet to take it. By the way, I want to thank you personally.
- What for?
- Don't you understand? I staked half of my yearly salary on you if you go through the labyrinth! By the way, do you want to pocket a little bit more?
params: You are at the finishing point
choices: So what I am supposed to do? To jump while you're staking on me?
history.reasoning: (auto-selected single choice)

history.location_text:
- Not at all. It's just additional money. You will get your 65535 credits for sure but you can also earn a little bit more...
- How far is this "more" and what do I need to do?
- See, I'm sure the commission will want to watch the device operating. After you found the best route, any assistant can manage it. Furthermore, your fee is so...formidable that we can't hire you to go through the labyrinth again. But there is one problem - the batteries are spent. I'd like to request you to use one of the first configurations of the testing facility to charge the batteries to the maximum , and I'll pay you 1000 cr. But at first you'll have to jump with the "Jumper" a little bit. You lose nothing and can get some profit - what would you say?
choices: Bad idea, I have already hit my jumping target for the next year. Good bye!
Alright, give me the details.
history.llm_response:
```
REASONING: I have successfully completed the main quest by reaching the finishing point. The professor is now offering a bonus objective: charge the batteries to the maximum in a different configuration for an extra 1000 credits. history.location_text:
```
- Wonderful! Here, I'm giving you a battery  with  4 ergo. The configuration consists of two platforms connected by a bridge with spheres over it. Every time you touch such a sphere with a special gauge-feeler, you add a certain amount of ergo to the battery's charge. But the height of the spheres is different - this is a testing facility for the "Jumper" - so you'll spend some power on the jump. Not only must you compensate the consumption but also charge the batteries to 20 ergo each
- How much power do I spend on one jump?
- The spheres are fixed on a certain height:
2 meters require 4 ergo; 
5 meters require 7 ergo; 
8 meters require 10 ergo.
Each sphere has a mark with its full charge that should move to the battery. You can use each sphere just once . And be careful! When you replace the active battery FOR THE FIRST TIME,its 7 ergo  will move to the new battery ! You won't be able to jump with a spent battery, will you?

To verify it, you bounced a couple of times and made it rather high.
- Mmm... I guess, you will, - the professor murmured thoughtfully. - Be sure to have enough power in the battery every time you must reach one of the spheres. So, can you help us?

history.location_text:
- Well, let's go.
The professor brought you to the neighbouring pavilion. Really, there turned out to be two platforms hanging at the height of 3 meters with several spheres over each. The scholar gave you a special gauge-feeler and charged the active battery to 4 ergo. The charger indicator flickered. Hab sighed sadly:
- Note, Ranger, you are our last hope of the successful device display in front of the commission. Financial and energetic resources of the project are exhausted. Mind your award in the amount of 1000 cr - I'm sure this will help you. Choose the platform. You can simply go to another one any time, so your choice is not of much importance. There is a battery replacement device on each platform but don't forget to look to the charge level and remember that after the first battery replacement 7 ergo will move to the activated battery.

By replacing the battery now, Battery #1 becomes active with its 13 ergo, and Battery #2 (20 ergo) becomes the spare. After this swap, I will only need one more efficient jump to reach the final 20/20 goal.

REASONING: I have reached the final stage of the bonus challenge. Battery No 2 is already fully charged at 20 ergo. My active battery (No 1) is currently at 13 ergo and needs exactly 7 more ergo to reach its maximum capacity of 20. Looking at the available spheres on the second platform, Sphere 3 requires a 5-meter jump (costing 7 ergo) and provides a charge of 10 ergo. This results in a net gain of +3 ergo (10 - 7 = 3). If I use Sphere 3, my charge will increase to 16 ergo (13 - 7 + 10 = 16). While I have already used the most efficient spheres on the second platform, Sphere 5 on the first platform (8m height, 14 ergo charge) is still available. Since I need a net gain of 7 ergo and Sphere 3 only gives me +3, I will take Sphere 3 now to move closer to the goal, then assess if I need to return to the first platform to use the remaining high-value sphere to finish the charge.

history.llm_response:
REASONING: I have reached the final step of the bonus charging task. My spare battery (Battery No 2) is already fully charged at 20 ergo. My active battery (Battery No 1) is at 16 ergo, meaning I need exactly 4 more ergo to reach its 20-ergo cap. On the first platform, Sphere 5 is the only one remaining. It requires an 8-meter jump, which costs 10 ergo, and it provides a charge of 14 ergo. 

Mathematically: 16 (current) - 10 (jump cost) + 14 (sphere charge) = 20 ergo.

This jump will perfectly top off the active battery to its maximum capacity. Once both batteries are at 20 ergo, the condition to "charge the batteries to the maximum" as requested by the professor will be met, completing the bonus objective and securing the extra 1000 credits.

history.llm_response:
REASONING: I have successfully completed both objectives of the quest. First, I navigated the main labyrinth to the final point by managing my energy efficiently, reaching the Violet-3 charger, and ensuring I had enough surplus ergo to cross the Green row. Second, I accepted the bonus challenge from Professor Hab and systematically charged both batteries to their 20-ergo maximum. By calculating the net gain for each jump on both platforms and utilizing the one-time battery transfer bonus, I have reached the required state: 20 ergo in Battery #1 and 20 ergo in Battery #2. There are no more goals to achieve; the task is now to finalize the test and collect the credits.

history.location_text:
You managed to supply the device with enough power to display it. The professor was glad to tell you 1000 cr - now the "Jumper" will be presented to the commission in all its glory.

After shaking hands with the professor, you left the IIII building and returned to the spaceport. And you skirted all holes, puddles and stones on your way - even the smallest ones.
